												My Medieval 2 Campaign as Milan:-Start campaign-Have Milan and Genoa, making tons of money-Ok, ally with Venice-No nearby rebels, what to do...-Venice attacks Genoa for ABSOLUTELY no reason-Kill Venetian faction leader-March huge army to Venice, Venice falls-Take Zagreb, Ragusa, and Durazzo from Venetianse-Crusade called on Cairo-Pope thinks I am a threat to Catholicism and demands Duke Puccio joins the crusade on Cairo-Join Crusade-Exterminate Cairo-France excommunicated for having 8 heretics in their borders and 12% Catholicism in Paris region-Pope takes Marseille, makes it their capital-A new threat in the East? Shouldn't affect me...-Trade Cairo for RomeAnd then it all went South...-I own Milan, Genoa, Venice, Bern, Florence, Staufen, Innsbruck, Vienna, Thesslonica, Durazzo, Corinth, Ajaccio, Tripoli, and Nuremburg.-France reconciled-French declare war on me-French attacks an army of 8 broken lances with their king ONLY-French take Marseille from Pope-France excommunicated-Milan excommunicated-Mongols come out of nowhere and take Corinth, Constantinople, Durazzo, and Thessalonica-Black Plague breaks out-Kills off 2/3 of my empires population-Cairo rebels-Pope is homeless-HRE declares war-HRE takes Staufen and Bern-Armies crippled Borders shrinking, economy failing-Use what little I have left to buy a city off of the Moors-Italian Penninsula fallsEnd Result-Milan has become a one city faction based in Timbuktu-France is a bunch of heretic witches with magic sticks-Africa now speaks Italian.And I didn't even bring up the Timurids, and their armoured elephants with cannons on their backs!11/10 Would build self destructing Roman Empire again

content:
21, 2015
												So I dug this game out of my library and have been playing it a lot recently.Started up a game as England because why not.I take over Whales and what's left of England. Then I start my war with Scotland. It goes as well as can be expected they have two cities I have...lots. It ends pretty fast. However just before Great Britan becomes unified I am excommunicated from the church. No matter William the Fatty dies soon enough and I am back in. I then set out on my duty like any good Catholic Lord does and Chritianize this land I have taken.Everything is going well. Our cities are growing in England, and on mainland Europe we managed to take over Brittany and Belgium and Holland. With this new base of man power I believe it is time to bring the word of Christ to the lands of the heretics in the east!However just as I am about ready to go on the Crusade, France decides I am too threatening to them and declares war on me. No matter English dreams can wait, we will just have to take over this damned country first.The war progresses quickly. France is overwhelmed by the veteran soldiers of the English army, mostly consisting of militia, but they are English Militia so they get the job done.We take over Western France and push farther into French homeland, we even take Paris. Just when the war seems to be wrapping up the French call in the Milanese to help them. I never liked Milan and it never surprises me when they declare war. Soon enough the English standard is flying over Metz and Dijon and all that is left is Marseille and Milan's Italian holdings, they will fall soon enough.However on my march to South France I accidentally declare war on Portugal when they came to the aid of France in a battle. It is only small little Portugal and their Iberian holdings will be great for bringing the Sign Of The Cross to the Moors....someday.But alas. It seems England became to big for its breeches. The Not-Holy-Nor-Roman-And-Certainly-Not-An-Empire Holy Roman Empire declares war. UGH. This is going to take much longer than expected. And to make matters worse it seems at some point I was removed from the Church.  I only notice because apparently a Crusade was called On Toulouse, which I own.Whether I am now the Anti-Christ or not I was still English and I wasn't about to let some European trash walk into my realm and take it. So I fortify my holdings and wait for the coming storm of armies. In quick succession France, Milan, HRE, Portugal, Hungry and Spain join the Crusade. Not good.Having lost a king and a large handful of family members in the war so far I needed to be careful. So instead of invading their lands I let them come to me. Quick enough three armies are outside my stronghold outbumering me 2:3 (I had reinforced with an army made of entire cavalry).First up is Spain. I let them wait outside and build up siege equipment. Then they attack. It is over before it starts, since apparently Spaniards are made up of weak soldiers who don't even know how to hold a spear properly. Defeating them with minimal losses I turn my gase to the next foe, Hungry.They put up a better fight than the Spanish but they too are not match for English bravery, and are soon defeated and sent home to Eastern Europe to have their silly fights with the Poles and Rus'.The last army to face is the Germans. However I am seriously lacking in soldiers defending Toulouse and have to attack with my Cavalry army. Though at the start of the battle my general warns me that their army is made up of many spears, they have studied me well and it seems that only they will put up a good fight, it truly is time for brave hearts and brave deeds.England has the high ground on the battlefield and we swarm over them like a hoard of.....well angry English. The battle is over disappointingly fast. Their army is in retreat, it seems that even their emperor came to the battle but he too flees from the field like a woman. Our Light Cavalry, those dashing fellows they, catch up to him before he knows what happens and is my prisoner.I demand a ransom but he "claims" he doesn't have the money something about the international jewery shafting his economy. Nonsense. If he can't pay with his Florins then he will pay WITH HIS HEAD!Maybe executing the German Emperor wasn't the best idea but no matter, there is still a war to be won. I defeat the French, Portugese, and Milanese Crusading Armies in time and even branch out into Iberia and across the Rhine. Somewhat expectedly the Pope dies and a new one is elected, not much of a surprise he is Italian, and he hates me. But I still have dreams of one day reclaiming the Holy Land in the Name of Our Lord and Savior. So I send an assassin to kill the Pope. The first one fails but the next one doesn't and the Pope dies soon enough.Disappointingly the next one is German, well that can't be so he dies as well. The next is Polish. Well I don't have any problems with Poland so he can live, for now. He even allows me to return to the Church, I think things might be turning around. But when I go to defend my homeland against...someone it is all a blur by now, I am excomunicated again, what a disappointment I had high hopes for this new Pope but it seems he will go the same route as the last.However my greatest assassin, Christopher the Christian Killer fails me, not only does he fail me he gets himself killed and I am now at war with all of Christendom. With my last King dying from "mysterious causes", and most of my armies heavily wounded from the continuing war, I retreat. Pulling my forces back across all of France seeing all that I had fought so hard to make. Metz, my most recent conquest gone like an instant. Toulouse that I had held out against all odds when I was deemed "An Enemy Of The Faith". Antwerp, where strong soldiers had held out against constant German invasions for over two decades, indeed to was a hard pain to swallow but it had to be done, with the peasantry in open revolt by home from being removed from the Church for so long. I always knew the people would betray me given the chance. So the great armies of victorious England headed home back to farming, waiting, watching for the time when we could once again sail across the Channel and bring the word of Christ to the heathen.

content:
er 20, 2015
												I started with Rome: Total War and it was a great game. You picked an empire to control and used diplomacy, force, and cunning to grow. You manage armies, cities, and special units (spys/diplomats) in order to conquor Europe and surrounding areas.What Medieval II: Total War did was took Rome: Total War and made it even better. With the same mechanics and the addition of converting cities to forts and vice-versa the gameplay becomes even better. New units, new Factions, and a new map gave this series a well deserved title.I myself consider Medieval II: Total War to be the best game in the entire Total War franchise because instead of dumbing down the game (which is becoming rampant in the game industry) they took what they had and improved upon it instead.I recommend you buy this game if you are an intelligent person who enjoys to plan things out and act upon them with patience and coordination.Thanks for reading.

content:
28, 2015
												This game has stood the test of time. In an age of decline and ruin in strategy gaming, one's mind wanders back to the glory of the past, and that glory is Medieval 2 Total War. Forget for a moment, the horror of poor optimization, leave behind the decadance of overpriced DLC, and remember the greatness of heroic men battling on fields of Medieval Europe. From the rocky crags of Scotland to the sands of Arabia, this game has it all. You ask for unique factions? Medieval 2 has many. Want a good campaign without horrible AI and bad diplomacy? This game delivers.  Do you desire frenetic Free-for-all battles? This game has those too. Now, take your mind back to the present. Total War is not what it once was. Mourn for our dying franchise, for there was greatness once. There once was a light in the civilized world, and this was it, this was our finest hour.11/10. Master of Total War and High Emperor of Creative Assembly.

content:
ber 5, 2014
												I have clocked over 1000 hours on this game on the old retail DVD version. And all i can say is this is the best Total War game CA has released - and will probably ever release. Shogun and later games have their good sides but this one is still the best. Kingdoms expansion adds some 200-500 hours more of gameplay should you run out. Stainless Steel and some other unit expansion mods adds some hundreds more. Graphics are getting old and the good ol' AI is not that splendid. Not even with mods - but this game along with it's older brother in arms Rome Total War got things right on some things that CA persistently cannot reproduce anymore: pure fun, paper rock scissors -type of strategy that enables exciting and interesting meta-campaigns. (who cares about official campaign goals - these games are always more or less open ended). And lets not forget those exciting long battles. Later games brought more crashing and complexity and lost something on the road. Fun and entertainment value being the first ones who took a fatal trebuchet cow carcass shot to the neck.

content:
er 25, 2013
												If you love the time period and liked Rome Total War then this game is for you.  I was not that happy with the game until I learned how to effectively charge knights. In Rome Total War you simply double clicked on what you wanted dead. In Medieval ll  you have to keep your formation in line before attacking. This is accomplished be judging the ground between you and the enemy unit you want to decimate.  When you are at a run with your knights and they are formed up in line hit the attack order (Double click).  Hitting them head on is a must (unless they are pike men then hit them from the back) spearmen don't stand a chance when a formed charge hits them. The diplomacy in  this game is involved and steeped in history. The different agents can help you do things like cement alliances with marriage or steal money from other nations with merchants.  The pope has impact on your decisions when you are a catholic nation. The crusades are very fun and a good mini quest which will help you groom princes to become better kings. The family tree adds a personnel touch which makes you actually care about your generals. The availability of mods also makes this a great game for instance if you get tired of the same old game then you can download something like Stainless steel mod which overhauls the entire game.

number of helpful: 85 of 86 people (99%) found this review helpful13 people found this review funny
content:
y 6, 2016
												TL;DRAn overall excellent game that I would highly recommend to anyone.Now, for the detail. First, I'd like to say that I have played this game for far longer than my steam hours. I played the gold edition disk for about 3 years before adding it to steam. I'd estimate I have something in the 600 realm of hours, 700 if you include steam time.EDIT: 600/700 on gold edition CD. Add that to steam time.On to the actual game. This game is a fantastic and educational experience about the middle ages. Even though some of it is innacurate 95% is correct, and you will most likely learn at least a few things you didn't know. To start with you have the option of 5 different factions, and by destroying other factions you unlock them as playayable. (orrrrrrr, you could just go into the files and change it so you can play as all of them straight away :)The campaign map is a well designed and easy to look at part of the overall game, with a clear layout so that you can tell what is going on instantly. The controls and design for building and recruiting are made easy also, and the advisors are helpful to new players. (though annoying for more experienced ones) and you can get involved straight away.Now for the best part. The battles are an overall incredible experience where you can lead an army into various types of battles; from raiding and capturing a castle to a field war of skill. As you play more, you can win fought out battles that you normally would not be able to or if the odds are stacked against you, and you become a true commander and build your empire.The DLC (Kingdoms pack) is actually a very worthwhile DLC, bringing in 4 new campaigns packed with new factions, units and maps, however I would not recommend playing these until you have at least got the hang of the main campaign, as these are far more in depth and you will get more out of them after obtaining a basic level of experience.To conclude, this masterpiece is my personal favourite in the series and I'd strongly recommend you play this over any other Total War title. If you are considering it, buy it. If it goes on sale, even better. Buy it as a gift. I'm sure someone will love it.

content:
, 2016
Basic InformationTitle:  Medieval II Total WarDeveloper:  The Creative AssemblyPublisher:  SEGAGenre:  RTS/TBS hybridGeneral ImpressionI've been playing Medieval II Total War since it's launch in 2006. It was the first game in the Total War series to introduce texture diversity within the troops of a single unit. It remains one of my favorite strategy games, mainly for its easy to mod game engine, which sparked many high quality mods such as "The Long Road", "La Guerre de Cent Ans - The Hundred Years War" and "For King or Country: The English Civil War".Strong Points+ Pleasant graphics and sounds.+ High modding potential.+ Steam Trading Cards.Weak Points- 4 years per turn, in the vanilla campaigns.- No Achievements.Rating 10/10 This review was submitted for Imperial Reviews and Cubbes.

content:
11, 2014
												        Yet another amazing addition to the franchise! What Rome: Total War does, Medieval 2: Total War does better. The first thing  I would like to talk about are the graphics. They have tremendously been enhanced from Rome: Total War, and you don't need much of an upgrade if at all to play this game! Shining plate, and mail armor. A great amount of new units, and weapons. Even improved animations! Unlike Rome: Total War, many of the combat animations of the units have been synced with the enemies attacks and deaths as well. No longer is it a slash at the air and instantly killing the enemy, now it's a fluid stab to the ground that makes you feel like they are actually fighting. One of the features I found quite neat are the types of armor your unit has for their armor rating. Now your unit gets the look of their armor rating! If you have bronze, it is usually padded armor, silver is half-plate (Or mail, depending in unit type), and Gold is full plate (If your unit can be upgraded to gold)! Their weapons however, do not change, or at least I have not seen a difference. Combat is also quite different than Rome: total war. Your units take a second to actually respond to a command which makes more sense to me, and it is also much slower. The campaign map is nearly the same as Rome: Total War except it has some minor changes. Overall, if you like strategy games this is a must have in your library. Too long didn't read: Feature improvements, better animations, slower combat, new types of armor. Good game, buy.

content:
y 24, 2014
												Medieval II: Total War is a strategy game from Creative Assembly and published by SEGA. It is a sequel to the previous games, Rome: Total War. This time the game is set on medieval era.Medieval II: Total War retain many elements of gameplay from Rome: Total War with many enhancement such as the improved religion system and world events like the Christian Crusade or the Islamic Jihad. As a Christian Kingdom you can answer the call of The Pope the conquer the land considered infedel by them. Settlement are now divided into 2 type, a castle and a city. Settlement can be converted between.Graphics of Medieval II: Total War are improved in many ways from the previous game. Each soldier has a varying number of elements to him, such as arms, legs, body armour, shield heraldry, and so forth. Each element has a varying number of styles. Arrow and fire arrow effects feels more alive. Blood effects has also been introduced, but without gore effects.Medieval II: Total War is a great sequel of Total War series. Medieval era especially the Crusade era is one of many interesting setting in Total War. With improved graphics, the performance of the game still great, the game runs very optimized. I recommend this.Rating 9/10

content:
ry 21
												I went from conquering the Portugese, obliterating the Moors and waging war on France. The Pope disliked this, and ex-communicated me. As he called a crusade on my capital, I assassinated and replaced him with my own cardinal. My puppet pope brought me back to the Church, and called a crusade upon France, allowing me to take it with the help of most of the world. I then sailed to England, and took Scotland and burned their fields and exterminated their populace. The Mongols arrived and I eviscerated their horses upon my walls and stakes. After the Pope hailed me as a hero, I invaded Rome and the Papal State was no more, and I foguht my way through every Christian faction until I took Jerusalem, bringing a victory to my campaign.I then started in Middle Earth, Erebor being my new home. The people of Dale were nothing but an annoyance, so I siezed their homes and their docks, burning the MirkWood Elves to use as fuel for my fires. Sauron decided that I was to be removed, and sent his armies to my mountain. He broke upon Dwarven Steel like a water upon rock, and I marched upon Mordor, broke down the Black Gate and took Bara-Dur. Gondor cheered, as my armies marched on Minas Tirith and I became the new Chancellor of Gondor, putting an end to the reign of the Dark Lord and Men and Elves, and hailing a new age of Dwarven resolve.The Argonians were isolationists until I got a hold of them. We gathered our guerilla armies, and marched out of Black Marsh. We took the surrounding provinces, solidifying our hold upon Tamriel. The White City were threatened, but dared not oppose us. We fought a bloody war against the Khajiit, their deserts hindering our advance, but we triumphed in the end, putting an end to the bloody furbags. They became our armour and new home decorations. When the Daedric arrived, they could not hope to penetrate the Lizard agility of the armies, each one slipping through their grasp, their gates closing one by one, until finally their armies were defeated. Thus leaving the world in a state of uneasy peace.The amount of mods in this game makes it worth while, not to mention the large amount of content in the base game and DLC. I highly reccomend picking it up.

content:
17
 Despite it's old age, it's a masterpiece.Medieval II: Total War is one of the best strategy games I've played. It's both enjoyable in a strategical and personal sense.Lets just straight get into why.Gameplay- The game manages to be detailed with their strategy, forcing you to actually flank and position your troops. It doesn't just account to how large your force is or whose troops are more disciplined, though, those two are factors to consider as well. In multiplayer, you might even be able to factor in Psychological Warfare! It gets pretty in-depth. And I love that.- In the Campaign, your Generals, Merchants, Spies, Diplomats and Assassins can gain, lose, enhance and diminish traits. It forces you to treat them as actual people to win the war, not the game. Your General is too hot-headed? Have him take up an Administrative Role for a while...Oh, he's too scary? Have him spare the peasants. He's a good guy, despite all the villages he burned...Probably.- The building and unit descriptions are just superbly fun to read, I find myself spending minutes reading the buildings and units on the queue. As well as the trait descriptions..It makes the game more immersive.- General Speeches are just the best thing ever. They can either be very good, like "Pray now for the intercession of Saint Michael in our Imperial Cause..If you ride a horse, add a prayer to Saint Martin for your devotions!" Or they can be extremely savage, "They say that the French are better loves than fighters, this is true: Ask any goat, pig or other farmyard animal." And, my favorite, can be hilarious, "Well, here's the thing. I look at our foes, and all I see are a bunch of ♥♥♥♥-weasels!" These things don't matter. They don't. But they're so good. And the fact that the later Total War games remove this makes it feel like something was missing in their core.- If you're ever bored with native gameplay, the modding community is ready to make you waste more hours on their mods like Stainless Steel, Third Age, DarthMod, etc.- The dead bodies don't despawn. The unit sizes are 80-160 men per unit. Maybe even more. I think that speaks for itself. It does? Of course it does.- While the campaign is great, I can't deny, nor can anyone deny, the fact that the AI is bad. I'd like to take this short moment to just be thankful that it's not as dumb as Empire: Total War's..- The unit variety is very large at first, but after a few hours of gameplay, you'll start to realize how little it is..Community- The Community isn't very bad, but not very good either. From my experience, the people are usually nice, and everyone follows the rules given by the host. (And apologize if they accidentaly don't.) Though, you will still occassionaly run into rude people, cheaters, campers, etc. Still, I still find a lot of fun in Multiplayer.Graphics- The Graphics in Medieval II isn't very impressive, but it's not bad either. But hey, it's an old game, so the lack in graphics is justified. Besides, charging knights will still look epic in any Total War game, no matter the graphics.Experience- The best thing about any total war game, or any game, is the experience. I have so much misadventures and adventures in this great game. I had a great general who died in defense of our Great Capital. (His name was Richard the Fearless.) I had an Assassin who assassinated every Pope that was elected until only the Cardinal from my nation was left to be elected. (His name was Ezio Borgognion the Killer.) I had a faithful unit of Mailed Knights that I brought to in every single campaign since the moment they were recruited early into the campaign. It's just..It's great. To be honest, this is probably why Medieval II is considered one of the best strategy games, and one of the best Total War games. It's the adventures you get through this.TL;DRBattles - Multiplayer - 10/10 | Singleplayer - 8/10Campaign - Multiplayer - 9/10 | Singleplayer - 9/10Gameplay - 8/10Graphics - 8/10Community - 9/10Immersion - 13/10Overall - 10/10. Go get it, if you're a fan of Strategy, you won't regret it.Oh, I forgot to warn you. Do NOT ♥♥♥♥ with the Pope.

												-Start campaign as glorious english empire-Spam churches to get popes glorious attention-Get best relations with pope-Declare war on french-Take them over without pope excommunicating me-Spams churches again to please pope-Declares war on Spain and Portugal-Takes over spain and portugal w/ out getting excommunicating-Is unstoppable english empire-Fear me-Mongols invade-Start militarizing borders and expand to HRE-Has strong relations with pope still and takes HRE no problem-Relations are getting low now that HRE ded-Spam churches-Relations get higher-Starts wrecking everything in my path-Glorious english empire,taken over all of europe and a quarter of asia-Byzantine empire and the turks are ded-Fear my might-Mongols invade my city-Defends from mongol-They attack more cities-Eventually gets overwhelmed with armies-Cries as my best armies are defeated and thousands of hours of work are thrown in the fire as mongols take over everything11/10 would watch my empire crumble before my eyes againthe english empire rises againI started my game as England. Knowing betrayal can lurk in this game, I simply war against all and trust none.My first conquest was britannia. Scotland put up a good fight, however fell to England's power. The rebels were taken care of quite early.Now with the british isles under my control, I set my eyes on France. They owned a large deal of land, however were bankrupt and didnt have enough money for a good military force. I took this as my chance. I send a few armies over to deal with the French, and proved successful. The french king was slain by the blade of mine.With France under my control, I set my gaze upon Spain and Portugal. However, they would be more of a problem. They have the advantage in seas. Therefore, I sent multiple of my general's armies over to deal with them. We proved successful and eventually cut down spain. Portugal denied becoming a vassal, and was therefore absorbed into our glorious English Empire.Now with most of Western Europe under my control, I set my eyes upon the Holy Roman empire.They were taken down, however we took a good beating from the HRE. The pope calls a crusade upon one of our major military cities. Luckily, this place was already heavily guarded by my men. We were able to last through the crusade.Feeling angered from the Papal State's foolish act, I set my eyes away from the last 2 cities of HRE and onto the Papal States. The pope was going to die.The papal states were weak, being small to begin with either way. Now, I have the papal states under my control, and the Holy Roman Empire left in a glimpse of its former self. I finished off HRE, and realized the mongols were invading. I swiftly remembered the mistakes of my past, and garrisoned my heaviest armies onto my borders, expanding it cautiously.The mongols were close to us when the Byzantine Empire fell. Now i have quite a bit to look forward to.

												Total War: Warhammer just came out huh?Total war: Medieval 2 Warhammer End times just came out as well, all you need is M2TW and Kingdoms, and now you have the entire Warhammer world, instead of just a small patch of it.Perhaps your not into Warhammer? How about Lord of the Rings? Want to play as the orcs of morder, and bring back the one ring and see what happens?Perhaps you want to just relive the medieval times as a loyal Crusader, or warmongering Jihadist?Then Medieval 2: Total war is what you want.The modding community for this game is INSANE! There are mods which allow you to improve upon the base campaign significantly, to completely overhauling the game. This is something no other Total war in the franchise has nearly achieved. This game's modding community can beat anything CA puts out, the new Medieval 2: Warhammer End times mod that came out roughly around the same time Total War Warhammer came out, proves this.Buy this game. NOW. (Be sure to buy Kingdoms!)

												Definately has to be one of the best strategy games I have ever played. First of all, the gameplay offers a massive choice of nations and units each with their own traits. 17 different factions on top of long and short campaigns give a lot of room for different story paths and immense replayability. The mix of battles, diplomacy, family traits and strategy AI create a truly realistic and immersive game that offers an infinate number of choices to your next move, although the turn-based elements often feel oversimplified. It does have a solid real time combat foundation, but the AI is either really good or really bad depending on the difficulty setting. There is no middle ground. If you are new to real time strategy games, this one has a pretty steep learning curve. Even seasoned players may feel overwhelmed.One campaign can take days, even months of play time. However, sometimes the game can become a bit taxing to less motivated players (not that I'm complaining) and the AI during battles can often glitch. Whilst these glitches are mostly minor, they nevertheless break your immerson in the game and can be quite annoying when your soldiers glitch about instead of doing as they're told. Despite all its weaknesses, Med 2 is still a briliantly crafted game, its strategy mixed in with impressive graphics and cinematic music will keep you wound up in the Medieval age for thousands of hours.It's one of CA's best (Total War) games. It beats Empire, it beats Napoleon (which was rather a pile of garbage so that wasn't hard) and it beats Shogun2. I still like Medieval 2 better than anything that came after it.

content:
y 16
												Having played Rome 1 and its expansions, Empire, and Attila in addition to this one, I would have to say that Medieval II is still my favorite of the series. I spent countless hours, both on the disk version, and then later on the steam one conquering my enemies or desperately fighting off hordes of invaders from the East.There are plenty of excellent mods out there for just about anything you can imagine, but I never really felt the game needed mods to be enjoyable. In fact I probably have more time playing the stock version than I do with mods.For a game that's a little over 10 years old now, it's held up remarkably well, and I'd venture to say that it's one of my favorite strategy games of all time.Edit: Removed section about redeeming retail CD keys for a steam version, as that apparently no longer works. Sorry for the misinformation.

content:
2015
												This game was amazing at the time it came out. I totally loved it. But I would recommend to play it now, because attempts to bring the rich lore of the Lord of the Rings universe into the video game space have been about as successful as asking a hobbit to cut back to just five meals per day. Struggling under the weight of expectations and movie tie-ins, these games have left those desperate to explore Tolkien's engrossing world disappointed at best (looking at you Shadow of Mordor). It took a devoted team of modders to do what the triple-A titles could not, and the result is the mightily impressive Total War modification - The Third Age.


Medieval II is an old game, but it's worth playing again and again for the Lord of the Rings mod! 
Community Created Artwork for Medieval II: Total War
By: Burn







I love the Orcs (Uruks to be precisely) in this mod.

content:
y 3, 2016
												My honest opinion:The AI is what really stands out. It's just as competent in battle as Attila's (the most recent TW title) is, and does well in the campaign, too.The tactical (battle) part of the game has aged incredibly well, all things considered. The combat mechanics are robust, and abilities are important (though a bit 'busy' in terms of interface, and fire-at-will is not always enabled by default on units that are meant to only fight at range). The asymetry in rosters means that combat can really vary a good deal, yet the balance feels just right.The strategic (campaign) part of the game aged less well. It's certainly playable, and it, too, feels balanced yet complex, but I'd be lying if I said the user-interface was all that good. As campaign UI goes, it's somewhat cluttered IMO, though I'd argue it's probably better than N:TW's was.In technical stuff, it's really, really stable, something that inexplicably was not the case in Empire and N:TW... in those games, I seemed to get sound glitches on the campaign screen, crash during battles, and so forth pretty much every campaign, forcing constant saving to be ready. Here, though, the game never seems to glitch up or break down.In artistic stuff, the game does quite well. For the era it was made in, the unit cards are good, and the unit models are surprisingly detailed when you zoom all the way in. The music is great, too. And the voice-over is, as always, the one mixed-bag (aside from the campaign UI, which was mentioned above). Voice-over work is terrible for units, but acceptable for in-game advisor and narration of pre-battle stuff (in historical battles, etc.).Overall, is it worth it for $20.00? Well, without mods I could see arguements that $20.00 is too high... but bear in mind how long the game has existed and how many people made mods for it, and it becomes evident that there will be plenty of mods to wade through and try.So, I marginally recommend it. A decade ago, I'd say to pick it up in a heart-beat... today, it's still just as good, but should really be a bit cheaper given that you will want to get the Kingdoms expansion as well and, hey, it's a pretty old title now (both it and the ex-pack).On sale, though, it's a no-brainer: pick it up.

content:
ry 21, 2014
												Medieval II: Total War is probably my personal favorite entry in the Total War franchise. This is partially due to my love of the time period, partially due to my previous obsession with the original Medieval: Total War (if they added that to Steam, I'd snap it up in a heartbeat), but largely because it managed to find the perfect balance between complexity and simplicity when it comes to campaign options - a balance which later entries in the series have tried to reproduce but often fall to one side or the other in attempting.Like all Total War games, Medieval II features a turn-based strategy map where the player manages their armies and cities, and a real-time tactical battlefield where they play out combat against opponents' armies. Medieval II covers the medieval period of Europe (and includes northern Africa and portions of the Middle East), allowing your faction to attempt to conquer the entirety of the western world of the time.It's fantastic and an enormous timesink. The graphics hold up surprisingly well for a game that was almost released a decade ago, in large part because the spectacle is so based on the massive numbers in the armies instead of incredible detail on the individual units.Medieval II is a wonderful game, and I heartily recommend it to any strategy fans.

content:
ber 26, 2014
												A great TW Game, with very good grahics, good campaign map, and many other cool features. Gameplay is easy, and simple, with little experience in other TW games needed, though it does help to have a knowledge of TW games in general when playing *any* Total War game. Diplomacy is greatly improved, giving   the feture of seeing what the proposal's strength is(a HUGE plus, when compared to Empire's rather un-responsive AI Diplo), and the Campaign Map is of excellent quality(obviously not Rome II quality, as i is some years older, but still very good, and very detailed) Battles are great, with a good UI allowing full control of the battlefield, and immersive maps that truly do the game justice. Again, the graphics here are great, and very detailed in the city/castle making. Another big plus is the inclusion of the Family Tree, later removed, which is great for viewing whom is within an ever growing family, and who should be king(a great plus over having to kill off the un-desired heir in the previous Medieval: Total War XD).I cant give this game enough positive reviews, and have yet to come across anytihg negative.10/10 for me, well worth the purchase. Highly recommend during the currant Total War Weekend, and still after.

number of helpful: 21 of 24 people (88%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
, 2015
												Medieval II Total War is an interesting game that lives up to most expectationsThere isn't that much to say here. It's a good game that has some very obvious flaws. Flaws that are amusing in their own ways and can be fixed with some good mods if they bother you. For those who don't know it, The Total War series has essentially two different games in it. The tactical battles, which are great and on nearly all the screenshots - Letting you be a commander of your army and lead your men to victory. And secondly a strategic campaign in which you manage your nation and try to take over the world(In a short time if you go for the game's objectives, but it's a game- your objective is having fun). The weak spot in all of this is the AI. The AI is, to put it lightly, comparable to an inbred dog with downs. While some parts such as the tactical battles don't show it as much and has the AI do decent at tactics, the diplomacy and campaign AI can't figure out what's going on and seems to exist purely as something to facilitate interesting tactical battles.But enough about the AI, it's still a good game that can show you the slow, interesting change from medieval warfare to guns and cannons, and lets you use it all in your battles to conquer the world. Along with this you will possibly end up exploring the new world, dealing with the mongols and crusading. In the end, you can be sure that plenty of things will happen to keep you interested and there will be plenty of places to conquer. Mechanics such as religion, your faction's family tree, and actually having to pay attention to your finances mean you will be busy with your empire's details without forcing you to micromanage it all. Though that is an option if you want toAll in all, it's pretty good. Decent graphics, good gameplay, and a big campaign to keep you busy. It's not the best Total War game out there, but it's trying its best!

(americas, britannia, crusades, teutonic)-there is the ability (in expansions and mods) to make a hotseat. what a hotseat is, its like a multiplayer campaign but you can fill all the factions and play it with your friends (search more in videos at least)cons-its easy to exploit the ai and the game is kinda buggy when it comes to pathfinding (its still good tbh)-if you are a guy that likes only graphics then this is not the game for you (but i dont care about graphics)-i know that i said that the medieval 2 community is still big but it decreased recently (one of the reaons is because apollo left medieval 2 and plays only TA and medieval kingdoms and that forces them to play those mods to just send him replays)if i had an option i whould rate it a 10/10. its just the best total war with the best expansion. this is a MUST BUY TOTAL WAR

content:
ber 24, 2016
												TL:DRBest game ever. 9.95/10. Very good for strategy fans and those looking to get into strategy games. Fun!Long ReviewEasily my favourite and most played game of all time. Including my hours from before I had this amazing game on Steam I'd say I have 1000+, if not 2000+, hours. Perhaps even 3000+ hours. This is an amazing game.PROS
Graphics are nice considering how old this game is. Spend most of your time zoomed out anyway so it looks good.Campaigns fun. The AI are abysmal at times but it's nice to have a laugh every once in a while. Campagins usually play out differently each time although patterns do emerge. Change this by changing your playstyle.Seemingly limitless possiblities. Want to try and tackle the Papal States straight away? Go for it. Want to rebild the Roman Empire? Go for it. Want to be a noble highlander reclaiming the Holy Lands and build  Scottish Empire in the arid desert? Go for it.Battles are fun. Crushing enemies beneath your feet is fun. Creating one empire to rule them all is fun. Planning your next strike and best targets is fun. Mods can enhance you playtime by many more hundreds of hours. Every con has a solution or silver lining. DLC is great. Expands game time by even more! Adds interesting mechanics to mix things up. Music really enhances the atmosphere.CONS AI can be too easy to beat sometimes. Solution: Play multiplayer! Gun units seem to be a bit buggy and dont work 100% of the time. Seems to mostly be musketeers. Not really much of a problem. Just use other gun units. Diplomacy. AI don't make the best choices. Solution: The series is called  Total War  for a reason! Naval battle will be lacklustre for those who enjoy naval battles. You have to auto resolve but perhaps that is a good think since most of the naval battles in the Total War series aren't great. Units bug out on walls sometimes. Usually issuing the order again or telling the unit to walk instead of run, or vice-versa, fixes this.ConclusionThis is the best Total War game ever! Everything is fun! Gametime to Price ratio is through the roof! The only real problem is lack of multiplayer campaign. I would love to play campagin with my friends. There is hotseat but then you can't fight battles with and/or against your fellow players. Perhaps an HD remaster with tiny tweaks to diplomacy and unit balance and you will have the perfect game!Christendom will be awed by the game reviewed here today!Great games are like sweet nectar, come let us play this most rare and glorious game!Note: This review will be edited a lot when I find things to add and reword it to be more fluid. My comments will also probably be deleted and reposted slightly differently. They really need an edit comment option for people like myself!

content:
14, 2016
												So I decided to start as France because I LOVE heavy cavalry and I doubt anyone has done it so far.     I started my campaign by absorbing the nearby rebel settlements into my empire.  The first battle goes poorly, I only just barely win and only from capturing the center of the town, I am beginning to doubt if  France was the right choice.  The second battle, however, goes very well.  I use proper cavalry tactics and completely descimate the rebel settlement, adding it to my glorious French empire.  After that I begin dominating the map, settlement after settlement, battle after battle.  Finally, My empire is the largest, the strongest, the richest, the most advanced, and the most populated in the world.  I have also allied with the British, the Polish, and the Holy Roman Empire, with dreams of conquering the British Isles.     I am soon given that chance when I recruit a mercinary fleet of ships.  I get Military access from the foolish British and set my armies in key strategic locations.  The next turn, I execute order 66.  The British are taken off guard and I kill all but two of their generals, king included.  I then turn my eyes to their last territory, where their pretender king awaits.  My king's army marches forth to this English coward, and just when we have our siege equipment ready and our swords drawn, the other British general attacks us from the west.  Nevertheless, we have the advantage and as my my ballistas are aimed for their gate and my horses crush their western army and my troops storm their city and kill their king, but at a cost, my king is bravely killed as well.  Which is good, because we had been excommunicated from the church just prior and were finally let in at news that my "heathen" king had been killed.    Just as I make preperations to incorporate these accursed Islands into my empire I am betrayed.  As it turned out, HRE actually hated my Polish allies and decided to attack me as well.  I am enraged to see their sorry yellow and black hides besiege my forces in Metz.  I quickly show these traitors whose boss and wipe out their troops.  But then, their leader, alone, attacks some of my forces near Metz.  I am surprised he beat me with few casualties as he charged DIRECTLY INTO MY LINE OF SPEARS!  He then retreated directly into the stygnian depths of Germany where I could not reach him. No matter, revenge can wait till he's watched his country burn.  I begin hitting him, hard, and end up splitting their empire in half.  Unfortunately, In my viscious assault I am, again, excommunicated from the church.  Thankfully the pope dies and I am reconciled, and to top that, the new one is polish so HRE is then excommunicated.  Sadly the pope calls a crusade on Cairo, and if I don't send my leader, I'll be excommunicated.  So, I do what I must, and before too long, have a crusading army worthy of many gasps.     The crusade goes poorly, to put it mildly.  I end up, for no reason, having my men continuously desert to "find another party that will be more on track to the destination".  So I end up wasting thousands of florins on disloyal mercinaries who constantly desert me.  By the time I make it to Cairo, the crusade is over and I am lacking in any reasonable army.  So I start back to paris.  On the way there I reach Constantinopel and notice it is lacking in any good military, and just can't resist taking it from the Byzantines.  Back in Europe I have finally taken over the British Isles and was attacked by Spain, who happened to be allied with the HRE.  Now I am in a war on three fronts and have the number one military in the entire world.  And one more thing.  Word has reached me that the mongols have risen so now I seem doomed.     Nevertheless, I manage to take two spanish cities and most of Byzantium.  After that, all that happens are pointless bloody battles that leave thousands dead in their wake.  Finally, gunpowder is made, and France is pushed into a new golden age.  I conquer the Spaniards and the Moors, I take all of Germany and exicute their king, and I destroy the rest of the Byzantines.  It seems france will never be beaten.  Then, just as I attack Jerusalem (my victory region), The Mongols attack me and a hopeless battle is fought.  My troops fight like true men, and for every dead Frenchman, 5 more Mongols die.  I loose the battle and swore vengeance on the Mongols.     I start World War 1 with all of Europe facing against the mongols.  And after years of costly battles, me and my allies make it to their main capital city which, ironically, is Cairo.  We barely win the battle.  For years the world is at peace.  Then, the Timurids attack, and it all goes awry.  They take over the Papal states, and much of eastern Europe (including Byzantium).  My troops are barely able to defend what is left of France, and I do not know if any other European nations survived.  The Pope betray's me and takes Cairo to start a new eastern catholic civilization.END RESULT:-Europe and Asia are controlled by only three major nations (France, Timurids, and Papal States), all of which are constantly at each others throats.-America is where the capital of France lies, and is slowly being taken from the Aztecs.-There are unconfirmed rumors that Milan survived and currently owns part of south-east Asia.-I hope for luck and divine intervention as the Timurids are slowly closing in on the America's.-The world is plagued with inquisitors and pagans, all whom corrupt the lands and murder people.-No one's faith is seen as "satisfying" from the Pope's perspective, and crusades/jihads are constantly being called on me.                                                             Fin(P.S. GLORY TO FRANCE!!!!!)

												Decided to start a game a england. Easy peasy i thought. In a 200 years i was already in control of the British Isles,all of France and even lil Scily. I was also one of the most christian of all the christain kingdoms. I could've called a crusade on ANYONE i didn't like. All was good right. Then the Milanese attacked. See during my entire game these spaghetti eating ♥♥♥♥s would constantly antagonize me. Whenever they attacked i would smash through their puny armies and march right up to Milan itself, sometimes taking it and forcing them  to relocate to Venice or Genoa. I've killed more Doges then i could count. But i've never been able to completly rid myself of them. See for some reason that litteraly god only knows, the pope would demand i end my war with them whenever i was about to finish them off. So for about 50 or so years we played this game of mudering each other until the pope forced us, mostly just me, to stop. Eventually i just had enough. My kingdom was begining to fall and i could not handle to pay my way out of another war i could have won. The plague was ravaging its way across europe and i feared the french Nobility might have been planing to rebel. So when Milan attacked like they always did i played the game right up to where it always ended. With their remaing forces cowering behind the walls of milan or Venice as my galliant Generals prepared to storm the city and fly the banner of the three Lions from its walls. Like always the pope decided that i had my fun and i should apologize to milan like usual. But not this time, no this time i said ♥♥♥♥ you Pope and took milan, Killing their doge and destroying their entire army. Now you'd think this is where the story would end right? The good guys defying the odds and finally defeating their age old rival right? sadly this isn't the end nor will the end be so Romantic.See after taking Milan, the Pope excomunicated me for defying him. Which made me public enemy Number 1 to even my closets allies. On top of that the Milanese regrouped in venice and trapped my men in Milan. If they went to take venice then they would lose milan to a greater force but if they stayed in milan then the Milanese would have more the time to rebuild. I was prepared to counter this by sending more forces into italy. But right as my men begin to enter italy from southern france, i get invaded. See my age old ally and undisputed ruler of Iberia, Spain, Decides to launch a full scale invasion over the mountains. Destroying what little resistance remained.So here i stand. Ruler of a heretical empire that's barely holding together and being betrayed by its closest allies hoping to carve out part of it before it collapses like vulchers circling a dying animal. All becuase the Pope refused to let me have justice.10/10

content:
16, 2016
												One of the very best games ever made. Some of the old, great games perhaps do not age very well, but a few are timeless simply because of their quality. No frills, no gimmicks, no set pieces, no cover systems or achievements - just gameplay and game design in it's purest, most endearing form. Medieval II is one of these games.The game, in typical Total War fashion, involves economy, politics and army management with the ultimate aim of meeting  certain victory conditions, which will vary for each faction. A world map acts as the main user interface of the campaign, but the majority of gameplay will happen in the series' trademark - the battles.In my opinion, this is the greatest game in the Total War franchise. Rome I had more varied unit rosters and was truly groundbreaking for it's time, but Medieval II is just Total War perfection. Hitting the "sweet spot" for complexity, political obstacles and size of the campaign map, the game has, whether by design or accident, remained the most (obssessively!) playable Total War to date. The difficulty levels of the campaign feel "just right", whether you are new and play on easy or normal, or want more of a challenge and pick legendary. This was the first Total War game I played, and increasing the difficulty felt organic and like a real progression.Everything just comes together in a way which will be evident if you have played any other Total War titles, but regardless of that fact, the campaign is the best experience Total War has to offer. Battles are at their best in the series, with a level of strategic depth which keeps a dedicated online battling community alive to this day, but with an accessibility and satisfaction which makes you want to learn. Winning a campaign, defending a castle against the odds and winning online battles are some of the most rewarding feelings I've ever felt in games. The battles here are Total War at it's best. Every unit has a purpose and a counter, and winning a battle feels truly tactical. Unit speeds feel perfect, and units engaging each other feels crisp, unlike the floaty cluster effect seen in later games in the series. Losing a battle will always be down to a tactical error which will have you wanting to learn and coming back for more. If they managed to break your infantry lines with a clever charge strategy, you will feel like you were outsmarted. There are no gimmicks.The atmopshere of the game is good - the medieval setting and campaign map match the visuals and the soundtrack well. Despite being an old, outdated game, there is a certain charm to the graphics, which makes it stand the test of time as opposed to Rome I, which has poor visuals to the point where it intrudes on the gameplay. Very few games have charming visuals which can stand the test of time, and this is one of them. To illustrate what I mean, others might include the Pokemon series and the Jedi Knight series. Whilst not the strongest point of the game, it does not, however, detract from the gameplay, which is the important part.The only one gripe I can think of is that the armored knights and cavalry might be too cliché and similar for some. A conquistador in full plate armor and an English Knight in full plate armor look similar, with only the heraldry and colours making them identifiable. Personally, however, I never minded this, but it is one issue people have when discussing why Rome I might be better - Rome I had very varied and visually distinct units.An extremely engrossing game, one of the best of all time, I can't hesitate to recommend this. While not as groundbreaking for it's time as Rome I, which is the darling of the series, this is the better, more refined and perfected title.

content:
y 3, 2016
 Medieval 2 Total War- where do I start...? Medieval 2 Total War is the fourth game in  the Total War series. It is a combination of turn-based camping and real time battles. Medieval 2 TW is a great game for every fan of the medieval time period and for every fan of a good strategy game. The Grand camping is great fun as in every Total War game, but when it comes to real time battles, Medieval 2 stands out. Player can set his own custom battles, where he can choose variety of factions to play. Custom battles can be ground battles or sieges of villages, towns, castles, forts etc. I find custom battles really epic and fun to watch. Watching artillery breaking down walls and killing loads of men is just great fun.Another great thing in this game is multiplayer. You can play coop camping with your buddy or join/host a loby and play some epic battles/sieges with up to 8 players.With M2TW Kingdons, you get 4 new DLCs and they come with their own campings, factions and units. Every DLC brings a new time period so you can experience the whole Middle Age from Crusades to finding America. And now, drums please...... The MODS. Oh, yes... Good mods are what TW games are known for. There is a great modding community for this game. Mods like Westeros Total War, Elder Scrolls Total War, Third Age Total War etc. make a whole new game out of Medieval 2. My favourite mod is Third Age Total War which adds 2 new campings (Third Age Camping and The Fellowship Camping). This mod changes all the faction in the game with factions from Tolkien's Lord of the Rings books. There are Orcs of Misty Mountain, Mordor, Gundabad, Gondor, Rohan, Elves, Dwarves... Every faction has it's own units (yes, there are orcs, trolls, even Sauron, Balrog and  other iconic characters from the Middle Earth) and every unit looks like it came from the LotR movies. A good number of these mods can be played online! MY CONCLUSION If you like medieval time period, if you like knights and epic battles, hell even if you just like Lord of the Rings, get this game (with Kingdoms DLC if you want to mod it!). You can get this game for 1-5 dollars on sites like ♥♥♥♥♥ and it is definitely worth it's full price! (not like some other Total War games, sadly).

content:
6, 2015
												A much more "modern" version of Rome Total War. Only this time it takes place during the Medieval period.You run historical empires during this period as your object like all total war games is to rule over the land. Unlike in Rome: Total War where missions are everything and you have to complete these in order to ascend to the top. This loosen's those restraints and allows you to govern over your lands without the need to do an objective every five minutes. The new SPQR is the Roman Catholic Church. Pay your dues to the church within this game and the Pope will appericate you a lot and thereby will allow some things from you within good reason.The UI for both battle and strategy is a lot more better and a lot more direct than Rome:Total War. The game also provides another detailed tutorial for first timers so you won't have any headaches when your play hours on this game is done.If you want a more updated version of Rome: Total War then buy this today! I recommend it

												In my opinion, Medieval 2 is far more enjoyable than any Total War game that has come after it (out of the ones I have played, atleast: Empire, Napoleon, Shogun, and Rome 2). You get more of a classic sense immersion from this one. Taking a young lad to lead a meager peasant band to subjugate an independant city, having him gain experiance, a title, special traits and an army that contains hardened veterans aswell as mercenaries recruited from various campaigns all over the Meditarianian and beyond is simply pure fun. Units react more organically and tactics can truely overcome superior units, unlike some situations in newer titles. The mod scene really makes this game shine. Warhammer (Rage of the Dark Gods), Lord of the Rings (Third Age), or maybe just an enhanced Medieval experiance (Stainless Steel) add and increase tons more playability and enjoyment to an already very good game.

"Despite it's high age, Medieval II is propably the best single player Total War game to date."What makes this game's campaigns the most enjoyable for me are the historic events that pop during the game. content:
y 17
												For me, Medieval 2 was the second of the TW series. In many ways it had the same attractions as rome 1. It's a very subtle upgrade on Rome 1, and whilst using the same engine, it is an improvement on Rome 1 in many small ways. The advent of historical events, and the players ability to influence flavours the game in a rather pro-historical attitude. Once again campaign actions are mirrored by those on the battlefield, and the more complex and dynamic AI makes for an enticing potential challenge. Overall, I heavily recommend this game.

number of helpful: 13 of 14 people (93%) found this review helpful
content:
1, 2016
												This game is the best Total War game in existence. This is by far my favourite. Not only are the vanilla and expansion campaigns a lot of fun, but the almost infinite fantastic mods adds the replayability of this game a thousand fold. Pros- Campaign experience is awesome. Lots of depth. Plenty to do. Complex enough that its not difficult to learn, but not easy to master either. It's so easy to get immersed into your kingdom and care about your subjucts. History is your oyster. You become what you want. You can be a benevolent king who's people adore, or a bloodthirsty tyrant that rules with an iron fist, a bumbling general that doesn't inspire his men at all, or the greatest commander alive who even peasants will fight to their death on his command. - More campaign stuff. Cities are realistic in that people actually live there and can be murdered upon sacking the city or plague occurs. The buildings you construct will be present on the battle map. Manpower limitations and recruitment pools disable players from spamming 1 unit type. You have to fill your ranks with a variety of units or wait a very long time for your perfect army. Crusades and Jihads are heaps of fun.- Battle pacing is perfect. The units don't kill each other in a matter of seconds with a bunch of fancy kill animations. They slug it out and get bloody. Everything depends on tactics. You don't just win because you bring lots of elite units. You have to outsmart your opponent or else your quality units won't count for much. - Sieges. No Total War game has more epic sieges than this. Sending four thousand men to assault a citadel garrisoned by half that number will take you a long time to win and push your tactical skills to the limit. 3 layers of walls require you to constantly think about reserving your artillery or your rams. If you run out of ammo or your rams break or theres nobody left to pick up a ladder with 1 wall ring left to go - well you're screwed and you have to retreat. It's awesome. If you are forced to retreat and come back the next turn and they haven't repaired the walls it's all damaged in the exact same way you left it. - The sound track is the best out of any Total War game- MODS. Third age, Westeros, Call of Warhammer, Stainless Steel. Just to name a few. Cons- The AI is pretty stupid and passive. If you're new to the game you might have some difficulty at first but once you understand the AI thought pattern its very easy to outsmart even on the hardest difficulty.  - The game is full of exploits and bugs that were never patched out. Overall I give this game 93/100. Which is pretty good considering I gave Warhammer 80/100. I'll still be playing Medieval 2 long after everyone forgets about Warhammer in a year or so.

But then Venice attacks one of the main Byzantine cities Thessalonica and takes it. I turn my attention West towards Venice I retake the city and head West. I reach the west coast and rather than head north, I build a fleet and attack Sicily taking Naples and the island of Sicily itself. Then I head north. You can probably see where this is going. I launch a succesfull attack on Rome and march further north and take Bolonga. By this point my army is highley exprience (some have gold exprience). But then Bolonga and Rome rebel I launch a second attack on rome which is unsuccesful. Rome was the entire objective of the campaign to reclaim Rome for true Romans (not like the Holy 'Roman' Empire). My Veteran army in Bolonga attacks the HRE army but they are reinforced.HRE - 4100 TroopsByzantuim - 1050 TroopsThis should of been the end of my Italian campaign but the 4100 strong HRE army was actually 3 armies the first army was quickly defeated and then the second came. My horse archers softened the second army up but soon ran out of ammo then the lines of infantry smash into each other my left flank had hidden troops that attacked the left of the HRE army. The HRE'S right broke and then the enemy army got outflanked they fled and we were so close to victory. And then another army came, this time roughly equal to the amount of men I had left but the last army had feudal knights, superior to my infantry who were also Exhausted. I sent every last man in... and then the HRE army completely shattered. After the defeats of the first 2 armies the 3rd army simply broke and ran. On that day 2000 HRE troops were captured and 1500 were killed but the Byzantine army took heavy casualties too. Nearly 50% of there army were killed but regardless they had won.Yes this really happened. Oh yeah the game yeah like uhhhh 10/10 Ign.

content:
ry 1, 2016
												Okay guys - brace yourselves! Long review incoming!*explosions*This game is exactly the sort of game I've been wanting. It sits in my library of Best Three Games: Medieval II: Total War, Age of Empires II (not the HD edition, that's a buggy mess), and Freedom Planet. :P (Grand Strategy, RTS, and.... platformer? What's this nutter up to! :P)It's a fantastic blend of turn-based strategy and real-time strategy.The whole Total War series is good, but Medieval II is extremely cheap. When on sale (and we all know how common those are!) you can get the game for $10 and the Kingdoms expansion for $5. Unlike later TW games, the Kingdoms expansion is a really really good DLC, adding FOUR WHOLE NEW CAMPIAGNS. Much better than one petty "culture pack." :PIf you don't know what Total War is, the screenshots & vidoes don't really do the game justice. Simply because there's SO MUCH to the game.Basically:On the campaign map, which in the main campaign goes from England to Russia to Egypt, you control things in a turn-based way. You make your moves, then another faction makes theirs, then another, etc. Because the game has about 20 factions for the Grand Campaign running it on a slow computer will be a bore. :PHowever, when you are attacked you don't fight in a turn-based way. Rather, you fight the battle in realtime. Whether you win or lose, your results are transferred to the main map. If you can't be bothered fighting (e.g. 10:1 odds or naval battles - in Med 2 you can't manually fight naval battles but it doesn't matter since navies are a side point), there is an autoresolve.There's spies, assassins, diplomats, merchants, wololos- er, priests which you can all use to further your objectives. Want to blitzkrieg? Open the gates with a spy. Can't be bothered killing a faction? Kill all their generals with assassins and rejoice in the Faction Destroyed notification. Send your Catholic Priests off to Egypt and laugh as either a) they cause Cairo to riot due to unrest or don't laugh because b) they all got assassinated.Don't fancy medieval times? Don't like the Pope? No problem - you can either assassinate the Pope and wait until you get gunpowder units for those, or you can browse the vast section of mods.Generally, mods are fairly easy to install and not too buggy.Medieval II also is the host of the most functional Lord of the Rings mod: Third Age Total War. It also has two subsets to that: Divide and Conquer, which stuffs the map full of factions / settlements, and Massive Overhaul Submod, which again expands... well, everything.And apparently there's "Hyrule Total War," a mod, which is apparently Zelda. For some silly reason there's a Rome 1 mod for Med 2, despite the fact that Rome 1 is cheaper (get it on sale for $4 :P).And there's also the four expansion campaigns which you can play to your desire.Multiplayer is rather fun, though custom battles (in which you fight opponents out of the blue and the campaign map is utterly ignored) have the problem of no ranking - you can find yourself fighting battles with somebody who you can steamroll because his cavalry never charges, only walk, or find yourself fighting battles with somebody who can steamroll YOU. :PThere's also Play By Email games, which are for the campaign map. It's time-consuming (and difficult, partly 'cause timezones) to fight battles actually against the other human player - it is possible, just difficult - and hence most games just use autoresolve. Nevertheless, it's a fun feature which shouldn't be ignored.The great thing about it is that no matter what skill level you are, you will be able to play & enjoy the game. Complete newb? Set difficulty to Easy and you'll never be fully conquered if you're vaguely competent. Veteran? Put the difficulty up and laugh as you steamroll the AI that took you 300 turns to do when you started.Mind you, the difficulty settings are misleading. The same AI is used - all that happens is that as you go up the difficulty, they get combat bonuses, free money, and free public order. Normal tends to give the most balanced game (not because their Peasants are suddenly deadly, but because the AI leaves cities with even less garrison than usual).Furthermore, the more you play the more you'll realise the game has a surprising level of detail that isn't immediately visible. Generals (and Agents, but Generals are more noticeable) have a system that I heard described as "RPG-like;" fight the French 10 times with one general and voila, he gets the trait "Hates the French:+2 command when fighting the French." An assassin missed your general? He might get paranoid and thus decrease how likely he is to die from assassination. Keep on executing prisoners with one general? Enemies will rout & run away quicker. Leave a general in a city doing nothing? He might lose loyalty.The economic system is simply masterful. Creating farms? Population growth goes up. Building roads? Trade income goes up, not just for your settlement but for the settlements it's trading with. Building a Market in a city in the middle of nowhere? Surprise surprise, your trade income went up by +6 (most units cost 300-800). Got gold nearby? Watch your mining profit soar.Mind you, people who are new to the game can just build things that make them money and not bother about it. More experience players can see how much money it will make them and wonder if it's worth doing.This game isn't for everybody. People who like to run around with guns blazing, die, respawn, have 10s of shooting, die, respawn, etc etc etc will not enjoy this game. But as for me, it's the best thing since Windows XP came out.It is also the only game that I can play and feel tired - not physically tired, but mentally fatigued. You can play the game with little thought at all, but you'll progress slowly. The more attention you put in, the quicker your WORLD CONQUEST begins.Still not convinced? Go get Rome Total War for $4 next Steam sale, see if you like the way it plays, and if you want to spend $12 (on sale) for five whole campaigns (plus a bucketload of complete mods, not some petty statistics change) go for it.(Note: Later Total War games are extremely expensive in comparison, so go get Rome 1 & Med II)

content:
, 2015
												I bought this game a year ago whilst it was on sale and I thought, "hey, this might be a cute little strategy game to play on my down time!" I was wrong...It took me a few weeks to learns how to play, which is fine by me because I like my games to have a little bit of depth to them and this was my first total war (which is bittersweet, because that's like being a virgin and having sex with a pornstar, only to have the rest of your experiences wanting). Anyways, I loaded up the game and started a new campaign as Scotland on very hard difficulty. I managed to conquer the British Isles in the name of Mel Gibson, which was good because my economy was sky rocketing. After a few years in game I had built up five full stacked armies of knights, armoured footmen, and archers. It was time to invade Normandy to liberate France from the HRE. I studied Allied WWII invasion plans for a while before I actually comitted to my attack. So I declared war on the factions inhabiting the Italian penisula and invaded mainland Europe on two fronts. Whilst I was fighting battle after battle, I got Russia to ally with me and attack the countries to the east of HRE. After a while, Russia and I completely obliterated the mainland. However, Russia wanted more land. A few turns later Russia declared war on me and we fought tooth and nail to secure our newly conquered lands. Russia was winning for a while, but then everything changed when the Mongols attack. We were both weak from fighting a mock WWII so the Mongols just steamrolled Russia. I tried to ally with the mighty Khan, but he refused me. In my weakened state, the factions of Iberia declared war on me and invaded the British Isles while the Mogols savaged my holdings in the mainland. Despite my best effort, Spain, Portugal, and the Mongols defeated my glorious empire. In the end, I failed my people, my God, and most importantly Mel Gibson.11/10 would fight a medieval WWII again.

content:
5, 2016
												If you want the definitive Total War experience Medieval 2 is it. Unlike new Total War games, Medieval 2 is much more complex in its gameplay mechanics. From maintaining merchants and diplomats to army management. Medieval 2 feels more of an empire building simulator than newer games such as Rome 2.  Battles feel much heavier and units tend to react more realistically to commands. The sense of weight makes battle feel much more organic than Shogun 2, Rome 2 or even Fantasy Warhammer.  If you do choose to buy this game, be sure to install Stainless Steel as it provides a much more historical early and late game era campaign. You can check out some footage of it on my YouTube channel.

content:
ry 27
Medieval II: Total War (TRADE MARK) is pretty cool, I guess. If I had to pick my second favorite Total War game it would probably be this one. You play as ruler of a nation during the feudal era of Europe and parts of Western and Central Asia. As this ruler it is your job to spread the dominance of your culture and religion across the old world while trading, bartering, negotiating, and fighting with other nations who are more than likely just going to be more heads on the pikes at the end of your campaign. It is a time of great uncertainty. The powers of the world won't stop calling one another mean names and every now and then you have to send a priest out to deal with a heretic in what is essentially a bible fight. Like Rome, Shogun, Medieval I, and the games after it, Medieval II is split between a campaign map and a battle map that changes depending on what location on the campaign map the battle takes place in. You still have the usual things, you build your cities, do diplomacy, move your armies around on the map, command huge armies in battle, things like that. So lets talk about all the neat little things Medieval II adds to the formula.One, there's an obvious graphical improvement. Medieval II looks miles better than Rome, and adds other improvements such as a change in unit models depending on their weapon and armor levels. If your peasant spearmen are equipped with chainmail then the chainmail will actually show on their models instead of it just being implied to be there. Second, the addition of religion and mercantilism adds another level of roleplaying to your campaign as you attempt to convert peoples of other faith or do battle with other merchants for economic resources and business rights. Third, new animations and battle damage are added to your armies. So sometimes you get to see a cool little animation where a soldier will beat up an an enemy and call him mean names. There's also blood, while not as gory as later Total War games, your units will get drenched in blood the longer they fight, indicating how long that individual  soldier has before biting it. And fourth, the soundtrack is probably the best Total War soundtrack to date. My personal opinion, but my opinion is great. There have been also a few events added to the campaign mode. Things such as the Mongol invasion, the black plague, discovering the new world, Crusades, Jihads, the Pope excommunicating you because you're too radical and he's tired of your skateboard phase. etc. Wow, all these cool things! So what's wrong?A few things. First, the AI once again doesn't like to cooperate. They're ask for trade rights, map information, and an alliance one turn and then attack you the next. Broken armies of 50 or so people will gladly die to your thousands rather than end the war, and the Pope always seems to demand that you stop a war you're winning even though more than not you didn't start it. He's that kind of school principle. But should you play Medieval II: The one with the armies, not the one with the skeleton guy? When it comes to the mid 2000 Total War games I feel like it comes down to preference. Do you prefer antiquity to feudalism? Or do you like Knights over Legionarries and Hoplites? Either or you can't go wrong with Medieval II. The additions to campaign mode are welcomed and there's plenty of meat there if you treat the Total War games more like a roleplaying game than a strategy game. I have about as much time on the physical copy of this one as I do in Rome: total War. And if you want, you can still technically play as the Roman Empire in the form of the Byzantines. It's not really the same thing, but hey, they're there. Also, the modding scene is friggin astounding. Everything from gameplay tweaks to full out new games.Two that stand out to me are "Thera: Legacy of The Great Torment" and "Third Age: Total War", the latter being a Lord of the Rings total conversion of the Kingdoms expansion pack.Medieval II: Total War gets a big number out of a big number.Odontophobia is the fear of teeth. The Curator: http://steamcommunity.com/groups/Dickbuttexperience#curation

												Whilst the graphics for this are slighlty outdated it has to be one of my favourite games of the series. The mechanics of the game feel fluid and very easy to grasp. Whether you have played the rest of the games in the series or this is where you want to start this game is fantastic. The mechanic to prevent you from recruiting armies of the best troops available and forces you to recruit a few lesser equipt units to bulk out your army.Overall the game for me would score 8/10, it loses points down to the outdated graphics and the factions having very similar units along with the lack of naval battles. It does gain points due to the recruitment system and the fact that it feels very fluid and immersive
