												For a game this old it sure is fun. I'm pretty sure it's like 10 years old at this point and it looks that way too, but it plays great. Second only to Shogun II. Seriously, Warhammer is nothing compared to this thing. Set in, of course, medieval europe. Fight in the crusades, conquer the americas, whatever you want. Call a crusade, even. Or, if you're not a fan of the church, you can kill the pope in battle and burn rome to the ground. Not even joking, the pope is a general, and if you edit some scripts you can play as him too. Look it up, it's quite simple, just most it from Non playable to unlocked and bam, play as the pope. You're welcome. Now go kill some popes, or be the pope, whatever you want.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
10, 2016
												  Played this game for over 400 hours and loved every minute. The base game was fantastic and offered a great mix of intellectual organization and also the opprotunity for roleplay elements, the world map being large enough to keep you satisfied with whichever nation you choose as it will always provide a challenge to turn that map one colour.  The DLC was also some of the best I've played in most likely any of the Total war Series. Each capturing a different period of medieval history while also providing a range of challenges. The America campaign being one of my favorites since it shifts the atmosphere of the game so radically.  Now as if the base game and DLC wasn't enough. the community has picked every piece of meat from the bone in terms of mods for the game which allow you to play as a lord of the Seven kingdoms of Westeros, the Uruks of Isengard or even just mods that increase realism and immersion.  This game has captured my attention for over 400 hours, and its been a solid experiance the entire time.9/10

												Wow! Where to start. This game really is brilliant, the graphics and scenery are really good, and the game play is so fun! custom battles, quick battles and historical battles are just the start and are all really fun. Onto the campaign, the campaign is brilliant and it really gives you a sense of medieval times, you can play as all different factions are conquer the world! i would highly recommend this game to everyone. If you like lord of the rings i would also recommend getting Third Age Total War which is an equally good mod for this game!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
ber 2, 2013
												My personal favorite in the Total War series. Medieval 2 gains a lot by being set in a time and place that is more or less easily recognizable to westerners. Assuming you start the game as the default English or French, you'll be mostly battling accross Europe with late game forays into northern Africa, western Russia, and the Middle East. Your units will, for the most part, also be familiar and easily understood. Even a casual student of medieval European history will understand why charging a spear wall with calvary is a bad idea, or why you don't use tight formations to advance into arrow or catapult fire. The game's medieval atmosphere is further boosted by a provocative musical score, accurate sound effects, and nation-themed voice dialogue. Gamplay in Medieval II, like any Total War game, is dividied between the strategic global campaign map and tactical maps where battles are played out. The strategic gameplay is solid, and players will be required to juggle tax income, religion, unrest, noble desires, and public health with the logistical demands of supporting your armies between battles. While the game lacks the research tech tree introduced in Empire, technology pacing is present through city building. As you build and upgrade your stables, archery ranges, and barracks you'll gain access to new troop types while smithies, jousting fields, and swordsmen guilds will enhance the equipment and quality of troops. Tactical gameplay is fantastic with players having strong control over formations, positioning, and abilities. Complexity is added in with morale and stamina mechanics, both of which are easily understood and implemented in a way that makes sense. The few faults that do exist in the tactical gameplay only emerge when directly comparing the game to more recent Total Wars, like Shogun 2 or Rome 2. Combat and unit cohesion in Medieval 2 can feel more rigid and unresponsive than its successors, but never enough to seriously impede gameplay.

content:
ry 26
TL;DRI got to execute the Pope, declare a Crusade on the Holy Roman Empire, and conquer the world and spread Milanese Italian fashion under the flag of Duke Bernardo the Mad, son of Duke Giorgio the Cuckold.9/10A MUST HAVE MEDIEVAL GENOCIDE SIMULATORPersonal InsightsThere's a myriad of sources out there that can cover the intricacies of gameplay far better than I could, so I'll try not to waste your time reading my review, when you could be in Medieval II fighting off 8 invading factions simultaneously, and outsmarting every enemy general on the battlefield.The GoodOutmaneuver enemy armies of better equipped knights and professional crossbowmen and win by epic, narrow margins with your  town militia and peasant archers in the early game, then laugh when you yourself raise armies of knights, and crush peasant armies with K/D ratios of 1:100 in the late game when you have so much excessive gold, you find yourself building Huge Cathedrals and Brothels in every corner of your empire just to drain your bloated treasury.There is no better feeling than when you've crushed all other factions except Denmark, Russia, Turkey, and Egypt, who then decide to form a super-alliance to prevent you from conquering the 20 remaining territories on the map, which you then do anyway.Unrest growing in a city? Raise taxes to Very High, move your entire garrison outside the city, and then wait. When the city rebels in 3-5 turns, besiege the city, kill the rebel soldiers, and then exterminate the populace to reestablish peace in your empire.Tired of using battering rams? Send 5 spies into an enemy castle for guaranteed access to Didney Worl! Laugh as the gates open as your troops surge through, and kill the French King to punish them for their crime of daring to proclaim French cuisine as superior to Italian.Artillery Elephants.When your general kills enough prisoners of war and exterminates the populations of enough cities, he can earn the epithet, "The Butcher". With 10 stars of command and 10 skulls of dread, Bindello the Butcher held off the Mongol invaders with little more than armies of Spear Militia and Peasant Crossbowmen. Unfortunately for him, Bindello the Butcher eventually died in an earthquake when I sent him to retire on the Iberian Peninsula.The BadVanilla AI sometimes fails to attack you with large enough armies. Vanilla AI sometimes lets you siege their capital for several turns, even though they have a full army nearby that could attack your besieging army, and break the siege.Executing Prisoners makes your faction "Untrustworthy". Why should enforcing capital punishment have any effect on trust?Vanilla AI will break a 50+ year old alliance to attack one of your lowest income villages, even though your army, wealth, and territories outnumber theirs by a ratio of 6:1.Vanilla AI will declare war by blockading one of your ports, and then failing to attack or do anything else for the next 80 years.Although Battle AI is mostly competent, if not brilliant, there have been a few scenarios in which opposing generals appear brain dead. If you siege a castle, and the AI has external reinforcements, the reinforcements have a decent chance of just camping outside the castle, and letting you slaughter its defenders without trying to aid their own faction.OnlineOnline experiences are limited to battles in the base game, although it appears you can run hotseat campaigns in the expansions. My experience with online multiplayer as been extremely limited, as my first online match was this year, more than a decade after this game was released. Nevertheless, I have been extremely satisfied with the handful of matches that I have had. Be warned though; in 2017 and beyond, it will be hard, if not impossible, to join an open match. Join some Medieval II groups, or tell your friends to buy this game if you want the most out of the online battles.ModsMy recommendations for modding the game? Play the game totally Vanilla for at least one long Grand Campaign, and then think carefully about what you would like changed. I put in over 200 hours in the Vanilla game before deciding to provide some tweaks to add some more options for gameplay. My current mods include Ultimate AI for the Campaign AI, and about 8 changes to the game files. Those changes are:Movement Speed increase for agents (but not armies)Increasing Age limit for Generals, so my 10 Star Generals stop dying at age 60.Increased Garrisons (free upkeep slots) for Cities and CastlesTrainable GeneralsStronger Walls/Gates, to make sieges a bigger challenge.Added Schiltrom (defense formation) to more unitsMisc. Diplomacy Fixes (easier Military Access)Misc. Mission FixesClosing ThoughtsMy experience with the Total War series actually began with the original Medieval: Total War. Medieval II has proven to be an improvement over nearly every asset of that game, and is actually compatible with modern hardware. If you like any other of the games in the Total War series, fictional Medieval scenarios, RTS's, or Eurocentricism simulators, I strongly recommend this game.TL;DRAs Milan, my faction was excommunicated for failing to stop annexing the territories of my Catholic neighbors. The Pope declared a Crusade to take back Rome, which I had annexed from the Papal States several turns earlier. Seeing as I controlled all of Europe except for England at that point, I decided to hunker down at Rome, and let the lone English Crusading army actually reach its intended destination. At Rome, I had a full garrison of high quality Milanese militia, led by three generals. Outside of Rome, I had placed another full army ouside the gates as reinforcements. When the English Crusaders arrived, I was somewhat worried, as the English had brought proper Knights and Armored Swordsmen, whereas I had Spear Militia and Cavalry Militia. Nevertheless, I waited for the English assault. Sure enough, the English began their assault on the walls of Rome with catapults and trebuchets. Yet, they never managed to see Rome's interior. My Cavalry Militia sallied out of the gates, and killed the artillery crew, while my reinforcements attacked the would-be Crusaders from the rear. The English Crusading army was destroyed, and as equal and just retaliation, I annexed the entire British Isles and exterminated their citizens for good measure.9/10This game is Machiavelli's wet dream.

												Wanna know how I got these hours? I'll sum it up in one word. Mods. Without all the beautiful mods, that have been created by an amazing community, I wouldn't have loved this game as much as I currently do. Without the mods it is still an amazing game. One of the best, if not the best current Total War. Amazing cavalry charge, beautiful arrow stagger, and even those awesome armor upgrades. If you want to start playing Total War then I urge you to buy this game. Does it have it's cons? Yes, yes it does. There are many bugs and glitches. I've encountered a few crashes, and since this an older game be ready for lag if you try to have the graphics and unit sizes to the highest setting. There have been a couple bugs that annoy the ever-living crap outta me. Such as during Sieges, you try to run your archers off the walls but half of them stay there. If you try to set them up behind the wall they were just on, prepare for stupid unit Ai. They form up against the buildings or something stupid like that.Even with the oldness, the bugs, the crashes. I still give this game a 10/10 because of the amazing mods it has.Third Age: Total WarElder Scrolls: Total WarCall of Warhammer: Total WarPlanetary War: Total WarJust to name the four I use. So buy it, buy Kingdoms with it. Then go on to download all the mods. If you don't then get excommunicated scrub.THIS MOD FOR TEST OF TIME NOMINATION!

content:

												Out of all the Total War games, I've liked Medieval II the most, mainly since it has enough mechanics to the gameplay without adding too much complexity that you end up using in the end.  As an example of this, I found the merchant mechanics pointless in Empire Total War when you're going for a conquest victory.  There's also a lot of content here with the new world discovery, and the Kingdoms expansion, which do more than just change the map around, especially with the new world scenario.  The downside is the AI can be very stupid at times, like when you're being sieged you can sallly out, and the enemy will for the most part stand still until you're close.  So for instance, you can use a balista or archers to take them all out if you position them on the flanks of the sieging army and you won't take any casualities.Aside from that, a really good buy, especially if you can get it on sale.

content:
, 2016
Medieval II: Total War™One of the best Total War titles with probably the best campaign.Medieval II: Total War throws you into the Middle Ages.You can choose from a good number of states like the Holy Roman Empire,Byzantine Empire,France,England,Scotland and so on.The game has Single Player,Multiplayer,Historical Battles and Custom Battles.You can save replays of your battles.GraphicsFor a game released in 2006,it looks good even to this day.So don't be afraid of the game's age.GameplayEach state has it's own victory conditions.Throughout the game,events like the Mongol Invasion or invention of powder will influence the way you play the game.Religion plays an important role in the game.The Pope can call a crusade while the Muslims can call a Jihad.Aside from generals and armies,you can recruit and use agents such as priests,spies,assassins,merchants and diplomats.Diplomacy in the game is decent,but doesn't have many options.The Real Time Strategy part of the game is great but it has it's problems.The AI will do weird things sometimes,and the unit pathing in the game is not that great.Mods and DLCYou can enhance this game by buying the DLC which also offers great campaign stories and other factions.By buying the DLC,you can also install mods.The best and most famous mod is the Stainless Steel mod.It pushes the game to it's maximum capacity,updating graphics,adding more factions,improving AI and more.

content:
er 6, 2014
												I got this when I put about 200 hours into Rome Total War I wanted more TW games so I found this and I like the middle ages so bought it.That was very wise (typical of me) as this is second to Rome Total War which I believe was the best game in the TW series I have a review for that but this is about Medieval 2:Total War which is a historically accurate RTS/TBS portrayal of the middle ages it features many factions eg.England France The Holy Roman Empire Poland Egypt Turkey Russia that's some of them it has in-depth mechanics and imersive gameplay where you will grow attachments to generals and actually feel some emotion when they die (goodbye maxed out at all skills general....) in Medieval 2 Tital War you will control a nation in of course the middle ages in the campaign skirmish and multiplayer if you don't know what the TW series is then read the next paragraph if you do skip it TW is a series of games that historically portrays periods throughout history it involves RTS battles aswell as a TBS campaign where you manage your nations finances military structures that are built etc.you will order units around the campaign map where they will get into battles that can be autoresolved or you an take direct control of the battle on an RTS map where you will control your forces against the enemy one in TW there us NO basebuildingThe game does howeer suffer from a very barebones multiplayer some balancing issues and a somehwat weak AI which can get to be a problem Pros:Historicaly accurate Large variety of factionsLarge faction rostersBoth an RTS and TBSVery in-depth mechanics Well made campaign Cons:Some units are overly expensive Some factions are incredibly superior compared to others Rubbish easy and medium difficulty AI hard offers some challenge Pope is very annoying Some factions are very unlikeable and some people will very rarely play themOverall this is a very good game and its pros greatly outway it's cons but if you are not a fan of the middle ages you will possibly not enjoy this game as it is trying to make an accurate portrayal of the middle ages so I will conclude this review at a 8/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
er 25, 2013
												One of the finest RTS games I have played and probably my only real favourite in the Total War series.  Within this game you start off as one of the monarchies of the medieval era, England, France, Spain etc, inhabiting the West with the Turks, Egyptians, the Moors etc controlling most of the Eastern regions.  And I use control loosely, for this game is about constant strife, border control and damning your so called allies to your own religious hierarchies.  The gameplay itself is split into two halves.  One half is the typical RTS strategic combat, where two armies with varied units, face each other on the battlefield to determine a victor!  In this part of the game, there is a Rock Paper Scissors style of strategy, with Spears besting Knights, Knights besting Archers and Archers besting Spears, though as your own technology expands and your coffers grow larger, more diverse units will be available to you.The AI can be a little stupid at times, often forgetting your commands or taking an insanely longer route than it needs to travel to reach it's destination.  So some micromanagement is needed there.  The second part of the gameplay is entirely Turn-Based.  You begin with a selection of territories relevant to your faction's Monarchy, you also have your own Royal Family who each have their own needs and quirks which affect your overall strategy.  And in this phase of the game you'll be charged with building your resources, exploring the world, and interacting with your neighbours.  Honestly I find this part of the game to actually be rather interesting, it's always fun to approach your neighbours with peace offerings and treaties, only to plan treachery for when the time is right.  And there are numerous and inventive ways you can attempt to accomplish this through, in a very Game of Thrones style of diplomacy if you're familiar with the subject matter.I found this to be the better of the Total War series.  Others will have their preferences to Rome, Shogun or maybe even the Napoleonic Wars, but if you have any doubts of either, just do your research.  I hope my review will help contribute to that.

content:
10, 2016
												  Played this game for over 400 hours and loved every minute. The base game was fantastic and offered a great mix of intellectual organization and also the opprotunity for roleplay elements, the world map being large enough to keep you satisfied with whichever nation you choose as it will always provide a challenge to turn that map one colour.  The DLC was also some of the best I've played in most likely any of the Total war Series. Each capturing a different period of medieval history while also providing a range of challenges. The America campaign being one of my favorites since it shifts the atmosphere of the game so radically.  Now as if the base game and DLC wasn't enough. the community has picked every piece of meat from the bone in terms of mods for the game which allow you to play as a lord of the Seven kingdoms of Westeros, the Uruks of Isengard or even just mods that increase realism and immersion.  This game has captured my attention for over 400 hours, and its been a solid experiance the entire time.9/10

content:

												Having played this since the original release and recently rebought it on steam, it is still absolutely worth the money and one of the best total war games ever made. Combining a blend of economic advancement, diplomatic shenanigans and military conquest, you definetely have room to manouvre with how you play with your faction, whatever your playstyle.Yes, there are some issues, such as ridiculously OP cavalry charges, scarily buggy battles on mountain terrain-style maps (some units are literally stuck and unreachable), and the AI's diplomatic nature completely unfathomable and changing (Always fun declaring war on the Papal States, conquering Rome then declaring a ceasefire by buying them off and then electing the new pope next turn with your legion of cardinals). However, these are miniscual when compared to how many hours you can plug away into this game and still really enjoy it, especially when you only begin to the tap into the mods that are available (Third age total war, Skyrim, Westeros e.t.c.).tl;dr: gr8 game, op cavalry, more skins then csgo, buy dis gam

content:
, 2016
												Medieval II is an magnificent game that will steal hours if not days from your life.  Important note though,  this game has a mix between  Turn-Based kingdom management  and  Real Time battles  so  if you don't like TBS or RTS games i don't think MII is for you.  Vanilla MII is a great game, but i personally suggest that you download either the StainlessSteel or the DarthMod mod conversions which change several game parameter and drastically increases the difficulty and adds tons of new content to the game. Diplomacy is pretty light but it is a forgivable feature due to this being a  Total War  game and the whole point is to wage war and conquer everything in sight. Vanilla AI pathfinding i horrible in sieges, but there are some mods that can fix it, although not fully. In conclusion, MII is a unforgettable game that is certainly worth the low price you pay for tons of hours of war and conquest.

												Wanna know how I got these hours? I'll sum it up in one word. Mods. Without all the beautiful mods, that have been created by an amazing community, I wouldn't have loved this game as much as I currently do. Without the mods it is still an amazing game. One of the best, if not the best current Total War. Amazing cavalry charge, beautiful arrow stagger, and even those awesome armor upgrades. If you want to start playing Total War then I urge you to buy this game. Does it have it's cons? Yes, yes it does. There are many bugs and glitches. I've encountered a few crashes, and since this an older game be ready for lag if you try to have the graphics and unit sizes to the highest setting. There have been a couple bugs that annoy the ever-living crap outta me. Such as during Sieges, you try to run your archers off the walls but half of them stay there. If you try to set them up behind the wall they were just on, prepare for stupid unit Ai. They form up against the buildings or something stupid like that.Even with the oldness, the bugs, the crashes. I still give this game a 10/10 because of the amazing mods it has.Third Age: Total WarElder Scrolls: Total WarCall of Warhammer: Total WarPlanetary War: Total WarJust to name the four I use. So buy it, buy Kingdoms with it. Then go on to download all the mods. If you don't then get excommunicated scrub.THIS MOD FOR TEST OF TIME NOMINATION!

content:
8, 2015
												Medieval 2: Total War is one of the best games from the Total War series. The game itself is really in-depth, and the strategy is so immersive and complex. Even the campaign map has hidden strategies for managing the diplomacy of your kingdom, which makes the seemingly uncalled for attacks from neighboring nations look a lot less random. The battlefields and units are designed very well and the whole game looks very polished. Battle strategies can be somewhat complex, but once you get the hang of them you will feel like a 5 star general. Not to mention the fact that you can even modify the game to play as the papal states, which has influence over most European factions. I haven't tried any big mods for this game yet, but I've heard about many of them, so it's nice to know that there are options out there in the unlikely event that I ever get bored with the main game. If you're looking to buy anything on Steam, this is a game you should seriously consider adding to your library. Happy warmongering!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
er 25, 2013
												One of the finest RTS games I have played and probably my only real favourite in the Total War series.  Within this game you start off as one of the monarchies of the medieval era, England, France, Spain etc, inhabiting the West with the Turks, Egyptians, the Moors etc controlling most of the Eastern regions.  And I use control loosely, for this game is about constant strife, border control and damning your so called allies to your own religious hierarchies.  The gameplay itself is split into two halves.  One half is the typical RTS strategic combat, where two armies with varied units, face each other on the battlefield to determine a victor!  In this part of the game, there is a Rock Paper Scissors style of strategy, with Spears besting Knights, Knights besting Archers and Archers besting Spears, though as your own technology expands and your coffers grow larger, more diverse units will be available to you.The AI can be a little stupid at times, often forgetting your commands or taking an insanely longer route than it needs to travel to reach it's destination.  So some micromanagement is needed there.  The second part of the gameplay is entirely Turn-Based.  You begin with a selection of territories relevant to your faction's Monarchy, you also have your own Royal Family who each have their own needs and quirks which affect your overall strategy.  And in this phase of the game you'll be charged with building your resources, exploring the world, and interacting with your neighbours.  Honestly I find this part of the game to actually be rather interesting, it's always fun to approach your neighbours with peace offerings and treaties, only to plan treachery for when the time is right.  And there are numerous and inventive ways you can attempt to accomplish this through, in a very Game of Thrones style of diplomacy if you're familiar with the subject matter.I found this to be the better of the Total War series.  Others will have their preferences to Rome, Shogun or maybe even the Napoleonic Wars, but if you have any doubts of either, just do your research.  I hope my review will help contribute to that.

												Such a great game. Well worth the money, well worth getting the Kingdoms DLC with it, just adds more to do really. Honestly, I would say this is the best out of the Total War series. I like the feature of being able to put units under AI command, have the AI take control of an army during a battle, though the AI is bad, it is still a handy feature if you want to witness giant battles. It is a shame they didn't include it in the later games. I love being able to buid up armies and attack huge castles with mighty siege equipment, it is just awesome.The game lacks some things, but it is old. There can be stressful moments, where the AI acts like a complete idiot, you cannot position your troops where you want to position them, some slight issues, but the game is still awesome and playable. Has some great mods out there for it, so you can go and experience them too.Highly recommend it.

												I am officially addicted to this game. Like the Football Manager series before me playing this game, it is very addictive and so much fun. Prior to purchasing Medieval II: Total War, I had only heard of the 'Rome II' edition which is the latest game in the series and the reviews didn't look too good for it, so I chose this, which I find a fascinating period in history. Anybody who is thinking of playing this game for the first time, give a couple of hours on a new campaign and once you get your head around how to play it, Medieval II: Total War is crackin' - Graphics are good, slightly dated, but the graphics aren't the sole reason you'd buy this game. I also bought the extensoin pack [Kingdoms] which allows you to pick from another variety of factions [eg Jerusalem/Crusades etc] - I can't praise the game enough. I love it and if you're looking for a great strategy game, steeped in history, this is for you. Enjoy.
